items.label: def-swarm-config-space
items.title: Swarm Configuration Space
items.content:
87: :label: def-swarm-config-space
88: 
89: The **full swarm configuration space** is:
90: 
91: $$
92: \Sigma_N^{\text{full}} = (\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V} \times \{0,1\})^N
93: 
94: $$
95: 
96: where:
97: - $\mathcal{X} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ is the position state space (Valid Domain)
98: - $\mathcal{V} = \{v \in \mathbb{R}^d : \|v\| \le V_{\text{alg}}\}$ is the velocity ball
99: - $\{0,1\}$ encodes the alive/dead status
100: 
101: The **alive subspace** is:
102: 
103: $$
104: \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}} = \{\mathcal{S} \in \Sigma_N^{\text{full}} : |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S})| \ge 1\}
105: 
106: $$

items.label: def-algorithmic-projection-space
items.title: Algorithmic Projection Space
items.content:
112: :label: def-algorithmic-projection-space
113: 
114: The **algorithmic space** $\mathcal{Y} \subset \mathbb{R}^m$ is the range of the projection map $\varphi: \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V} \to \mathbb{R}^m$.
115: 
116: For the canonical Geometric Gas with velocity weighting $\lambda_v > 0$:
117: 
118: $$
119: \varphi(x, v) = (x, \lambda_v v) \in \mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d = \mathbb{R}^{2d}
120: 
121: $$
122: 
123: Thus $m = 2d$ and $\mathcal{Y} = \mathcal{X} \times \lambda_v \mathcal{V}$.
124: 
125: The algorithmic metric is the **Sasaki metric**:
126: 
127: $$
128: d_{\mathcal{Y}}^2(\varphi(x_1, v_1), \varphi(x_2, v_2)) = \|x_1 - x_2\|^2 + \lambda_v^2 \|v_1 - v_2\|^2

items.label: def-symmetry-transformation
items.title: Symmetry Transformation
items.content:
136: :label: def-symmetry-transformation
137: 
138: A **symmetry** of a dynamical system $\mathcal{S}_{t+1} \sim \Psi(\mathcal{S}_t, \cdot)$ is a transformation $T: \Sigma_N \to \Sigma_N$ such that:
139: 
140: $$
141: T(\mathcal{S}_{t+1}) \sim \Psi(T(\mathcal{S}_t), \cdot)
142: 
143: $$
144: 
145: in distribution. That is, applying $T$ before or after the dynamics gives statistically equivalent outcomes.
146: 
147: **Types of symmetries:**
148: 1. **Exact symmetry**: The transition kernel is invariant: $\Psi(T(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot) \circ T^{-1}$
items.raw_directive:
133: ### 2.2. Symmetry Groups: Definitions
134: 
135: :::{prf:definition} Symmetry Transformation
136: :label: def-symmetry-transformation
137: 
138: A **symmetry** of a dynamical system $\mathcal{S}_{t+1} \sim \Psi(\mathcal{S}_t, \cdot)$ is a transformation $T: \Sigma_N \to \Sigma_N$ such that:
139: 
140: $$
141: T(\mathcal{S}_{t+1}) \sim \Psi(T(\mathcal{S}_t), \cdot)
142: 
143: $$
144: 
145: in distribution. That is, applying $T$ before or after the dynamics gives statistically equivalent outcomes.
146: 
147: **Types of symmetries:**
148: 1. **Exact symmetry**: The transition kernel is invariant: $\Psi(T(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot) \circ T^{-1}$
149: 2. **Statistical symmetry**: The quasi-stationary distribution (QSD) is invariant: $T_* \pi_{\text{QSD}} = \pi_{\text{QSD}}$

items.label: def-permutation-group
items.title: Permutation Group
items.content:
154: :label: def-permutation-group
155: 
156: The **symmetric group** $S_N$ acts on $\Sigma_N$ by permuting walker indices. For $\sigma \in S_N$:
157: 
158: $$
159: \sigma(\mathcal{S}) = ((x_{\sigma(1)}, v_{\sigma(1)}, s_{\sigma(1)}), \ldots, (x_{\sigma(N)}, v_{\sigma(N)}, s_{\sigma(N)}))
160: 
161: $$

items.label: def-euclidean-group-actions
items.title: Euclidean Group Actions
items.content:
167: :label: def-euclidean-group-actions
168: 
169: The **Euclidean group** $E(d) = \mathbb{R}^d \rtimes O(d)$ acts on $\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V}$.
170: 
171: **Translation subgroup** $\mathbb{R}^d$: For $a \in \mathbb{R}^d$,
172: 
173: $$
174: T_a(x, v, s) = (x + a, v, s)
175: 
176: $$
177: 
178: **Rotation subgroup** $SO(d)$: For $R \in SO(d)$,
179: 
180: $$
181: R(x, v, s) = (Rx, Rv, s)
182: 
183: $$

items.label: def-rho-fitness-potential
items.title: ρ-Localized Fitness Potential
items.content:
193: :label: def-rho-fitness-potential
194: 
195: For localization scale $\rho > 0$, the fitness potential at walker $i$ is:
196: 
197: $$
198: V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i, v_i) = \eta^{\alpha + \beta} \exp\left(\alpha Z_\rho[f_k, R, (x_i, v_i)] + \beta Z_\rho[f_k, d, (x_i, v_i)]\right)
199: 
200: $$
201: 
202: where:
203: - $f_k = \frac{1}{k}\sum_{j \in A_k} \delta_{(x_j, v_j)}$ is the empirical measure over alive walkers
204: - $Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z]$ is the localized Z-score:
205: 
206: $$
207: Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z] = \frac{Q(z) - \mu_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}{\sigma'_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}
208: 
209: $$
items.raw_directive:

199:

201: 
202: where:
203: - $f_k = \frac{1}{k}\sum_{j \in A_k} \delta_{(x_j, v_j)}$ is the empirical measure over alive walkers
204: - $Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z]$ is the localized Z-score:
205: 
206: $$
207: Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z] = \frac{Q(z) - \mu_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}{\sigma'_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}
208: 
209: $$

items.label: def-emergent-metric
items.title: Emergent Riemannian Metric
items.content:
215: :label: def-emergent-metric
216: 
217: The **emergent metric** is the regularized Hessian of the fitness potential:
218: 
219: $$
220: g(x_i, S) = H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I
221: 
222: $$
223: 
224: where:
225: 
226: $$
227: H_i(S) = \nabla^2_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i, v_i)
228: 
229: $$
230: 
231: The **adaptive diffusion tensor** is:
232: 
233: $$
234: D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) = g(x_i, S)^{-1}
235: 
236: $$
